Title.evidence: Methods:: A randomized, parallel, open-label trial in six university or regional hospitals in Sweden.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomized to either a physical activity intervention with aerobic activity and inspiratory muscle training 2 weeks pre- and 4 weeks postoperatively or usual care.

Participants.evidence: Inclusion criteria were age ≥20 years and planned elective colorectal cancer surgery.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomized to either a physical activity intervention with aerobic activity and inspiratory muscle training 2 weeks pre- and 4 weeks postoperatively or usual care.

Objective.evidence: Objective:: To determine the effect of a short-term, unsupervised exercise intervention before and after colorectal cancer surgery on self-assessed physical recovery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measure was self-assessed physical recovery 4 weeks postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomized to either a physical activity intervention with aerobic activity and inspiratory muscle training 2 weeks pre- and 4 weeks postoperatively or usual care.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were masked regarding the intervention while both participants and physiotherapists were informed due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between January 22, 2015, and May 28, 2020, 761 participants were recruited and assigned to either intervention (I) (n = 379) or control (C) (n = 382).

Number_Analysed.evidence: After exclusions 668 participants ( I = 317, C = 351) were included in the primary analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no effect from the intervention on the primary outcome measure (adjusted odds ratio 0.84, 95% confidence interval 0.62–1.15) with 13% and 15% of participants feeling fully physically recovered in I and C, respectively.

Harms.evidence: There were no reported adverse events.
